In Sanyika Shakur's memoir of gang life, Monster, he describes
the so-called LA riots in terms strikingly different from those used
in mass media accounts of that historic event. Where the New York
Times sees "rioting, looting, and burning" as manifestations of "the
anarchy sweeping the city," Shakur grasps the sequence of actions as
tactical, not anarchic, actions. Naming the event a "rebellion" rather
than a "riot" lets Shakur analyze it from another vantage:
The point I'm trying to make is that the businesses that
were destroyed were not owned and operated by people
who lived in those communities. They were owned and oper-
ated by folks who live in the suburban areas. The services
they were supplying were provided at astronomical prices,
and the products were often inferior. No matter how many
Toms try to paint a different scenario, there was a collective
consciousness among the oppressed that is evidenced in
their selection of targets and items taken. (381)
Indeed, Shakur tells his life as a conversion story—"from banger to
revolutionary"—because its generic passage from ideology to con-
sciousness is what permits him to tell the story in the first place.
Were it not a conversion story, that is, were he still a "ghetto star," he
would never have written a memoir because the ideological rendering
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
of events that the mass media proffered the public would likewise
be his own rendering of events. Shakur finds his story unreliably
told in another's voice, however, once he sees that certain literary
effects—the substitution of the words riot for rebellion, anarchy for
tactics—are part of the house style for establishment journalism. In
writing a memoir, then, he places his claim on the real account of
events over and against those who would purvey uncut ideology.
It is expected, of course, that one writing a memoir would lay
claim to realism, for we imagine this to be the genre's foundational
claim. What might surprise us, though, is the way in which Octavia
Butler places a comparable claim on realism when, on my read-
ing, she represents the same event, known elsewhere as the "Los
Angeles Civil Unrest," in her science fiction (SF) novel, The Parable
of the Sower.
Although narrated in a recognizably speculative key,
Butler's account doesn't differ materially from Shakur's or the New
York Times's; the referent is plainly the same, that is, even if the
rhetoric isn't. "I saw a guy get both of his eyes gouged out," reports
one of her characters, Keith Olamina, after traveling from suburban
Robledo into Los Angeles. "After that," he continues, "they set him
on fire and watched him run around and scream and burn" (97–98).
What withholds legitimacy from Butler's claim to realism, at least
in the commonsense appraisal that would grant it automatically to
memoirs and print journalism, is that in the western literary tradition
SF is presumed to have an attenuated, if not fully severed, link to
its author's empirical world.
A main premise of my argument is that
SF has posited itself as the mode of representation that can execute
the realist function in better faith than can other genres traditionally
identified with realism.
Since such founding statements as Darko
Suvin's, SF criticism has been committed to tracking the shifts of
generic plates, which has let critics see that the historic charge of SF
as a genre waxes in importance in our time.
This, I argue, is because
much that passes for realism has been reluctant to avow its literary
quality—the documentary, for instance, cannot admit its dependence
on style and invention without losing its genre privilege —whereas SF
foregrounds its literary quality. In fact, the imaginative infrastructure
in which its plots unfold is its raison d'être. My argument calls on a
distinction between empirical and fantastic writing underlying much SF
criticism. But it construes the distinction that Suvin finds between an
"extreme of exact recreation of the author’s empirical environment"
and an "interest in a strange newness, a novum" (373) in terms of
a difference often imputed to naturalism and realism: the former
being a kind of dumb mimesis, as Georg Lukács dismissed it, while
the latter is the forum in which contending voices, each bearing its
own style, shape the present.
Menne
On the way to assessing Butler's implicit claim on realism in
both Parable novels, Parable of the Sower and its sequel Parable of
the Talents, I want to juxtapose SF briefly with certain genres that
have intuitive realist claims—the memoir and the documentary. If
we turn to an account of earlier "race riots," Tom Hayden's memoir
of the 1967 uprising in Newark, Rebellion in Newark, we see Hayden
struggle to position his account against "official" reports. Mindful that
his own activism might taint his account as an interested one, he
writes of his hope that "this record of experiences is honest and clear
enough to be used by others" (4–5). Hayden's adjectives, "honest"
and "clear," suggest the qualities of realism that we might suppose
Shakur later tries to confer on his memoir, a kind of realism that
Michael Davitt Bell calls the "reflective model" that "denies the liter-
ary quality" of a work (2). We should note how the ingenuousness
of Hayden's honesty and clarity, the seemingly neutral workings of
transparent prose, is belied by his awareness that others might later
use his account. His account, then, is designed to specify its uses. And
this because he knows that official accounts, no merely transparent
reflections themselves, will be used to conceal the event's structural
causes. Hence, the doe-eyed style of his disclosure is a fully calculated
one, set against the cynical versions given by "leaders of the busi-
ness and political communities" (5) who would obscure the source of
"the law-breaking violence of the rioters" in the "original and greater
violence of racism" (3). Now, what makes Hayden's spinning of events
unique, when otherwise we might call it politics as usual, is the way
he theatricalizes the memoir form—his "record of experiences" as
one involved—as a rough equivalent to official statements. The tone
of objective reportage, as Hayden's language shows, is but a style
that grows conspicuous the more it effaces its interest in events, or
its influence on them.
This mode of representation that would repress its principle of
selection—Lukács termed it "description," or naturalism
—is one in
ascendancy, as Hayden sensed, in a media ecology in which the im-
age comes to displace the print media.
This is centrally so for the
LA Civil Unrest, precipitated as it was by an image-event.
But here
I wish to dwell on genre, not medium, by transferring the dynamic
at work in Hayden's representation into the context of documentary
filmmaking. Treating the recent documentary Food, Inc. as represen-
tative of storytelling modes in contemporary documentary, I wish to
consider it alongside another account of the fallout from genetically
modified organisms (GMOs), namely Margaret Atwood's Oryx and
Crake. By making this comparison, I will establish how the style of
documentary, while taken to have intuitive realist claims, is in fact
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
shot through with utopian and dystopian rhetoric. What this should
illuminate is not that documentary relinquishes its realist claims—not
of necessity, at least—when it uses utopian or dystopian effects, but
instead that such effects, depending on their handling, are not in-
compatible with realism. Instead, their compatibility will help explain
why SF stands as a strong form of realism while other modes of rep-
resentation, consigned here to naturalism for their self-effacement,
fall away from an ethics of public-sphere debate by disavowing the
"fine style" that the emblematic naturalist Frank Norris denounced
when he implored, "Tell your yarn and let your style go to the devil.
We don't want literature, we want life" (Bell 120).
In Food, Inc. we find a high degree of style; "literature," one
might say, in a genre identified with "life." The documentary begins
by proffering montage "imagery of agrarian America," as Michael
Pollan narrates it, that it will then undercut by showing how this
imagery, a mere "pastoral fantasy," has been deployed by a food
industry, comprising only several "huge, multinational corporations,"
that "does not want you to know the truth about what you're eating."
This story presents a public duped by a world whose naturalness is
simulated by an absent collection of faceless entities, a familiar dysto-
pian idiom. Once Pollan has laid bare the simulacrum—the falseness,
that is, of an agrarian world—we are placed behind a shopping cart,
and like automatons we move awkwardly through a fluorescent-lit
supermarket. Here, the voiceover tells us, "there are no seasons,"
as if evoking the domed atmospheres of such dystopias as Logan's
Run. We see what we imagine is a display of tomatoes, but what may
"look like a tomato," we're told, is only "a notional tomato." True to
the style of classic dystopias, the green world has been denatured,
fakes are substituted for the originals, and wherever we look in this
film, we find ourselves hemmed in by machines and the factory-farm
chimneys stacked against the horizon. Next to this highly mecha-
nized dystopia, though, the film depicts the utopian enclave of Joel
Salatin's Polyface Farm. Salatin is limned within his lush, sustainable
ecosystem, a throwback to our natural state, and his willingness to
speak in defense of his business practices, in logical and personable
tones, contrasts with the refrain we hear throughout that the large
corporations have "declined to be interviewed for the film." The film,
in short, makes unabashed use of the tropes of utopian and dysto-
pian storytelling.
Atwood's Oryx and Crake plays, too, in dystopian registers
(though Fredric Jameson describes it as "two utopias and a dysto-
pia . . . ingeniously intertwined" ["Then" 7]). While it begins amid
postapocalyptic ruins, with the protagonist Snowman struggling to
subsist, the narrative consists largely in a flashback to a recent past
that resembles the world of Food, Inc., though its brand names are
Menne
invented (HelthWyzer and OrganInc Farms), not borrowed (Perdue
and Monsanto). The bioengineered world that Atwood imagines, if
perhaps more accelerated in its production of GMOs (pigoons and
rakunks count among its fauna), is no more stylized than its nonfic-
tional counterpart. The difference between the two texts, I suggest,
concerns the scale on which dystopian outcomes are indexed—in the
film, outbreaks of E. coli are localized, though increasingly periodic,
while in the novel the pandemic ignites in a global flashpoint—less
than it does the transparency with which the texts reflect the world
of which they are a part. Both texts might be classed as realist, as
I will shortly make the case, in that both acknowledge that the ver-
sions of the world they offer their audience function as intervention-
ist accounts of a mutually constructed real world. The strategy that
Food, Inc. employs leads to a final chapter in which what seemed
like a sealed-in dystopia now offers its subjects, who now seem sub-
stantively like characters in a fiction, some hope of egress by way of
changing their habits of consumption. Oryx and Crake, rather than
ending with a similarly utopian flourish, concludes by presenting
Snowman an opening on human society once more. Snowman has
the choice, as he stalks a band of survivors—three fellow humans—to
communicate with them and begin constructing society anew. "They
could listen to him, they could hear his tale," he speculates, "he could
hear theirs" (374). The dark alternative is to kill them before they
kill him, and thus consecrate the dystopian collapse of society. The
novel ends there, in pure potentiality, but its last gesture nonetheless
reproduces the openness of Food, Inc., as each enlists a measure of
activeness from its audience once the text closes.
This digression on genre means to map the unlikely shared
space of documentary and SF in order to signal two developments:
first, that the realist mode can now operate as effectively in the host
genre of SF as in any other; and second, that this is so explicitly
because SF has developed in symbiosis with utopian and dystopian
form—which may be SF's "socioeconomic subgenre," as Suvin argues
(Metamorphoses 61), or it may be a kind of "logical operator," as
Slavoj Žižek has said of film noir, "introducing the same anamorphic
distortion in every genre to which it is applied" (10)—and as such SF
has become a privileged genre precisely because the utopian utter-
ance, as well as its negations, has become a nearly essential part of
realist discourse. These should be taken as historical claims about
realism and utopia. The first claim needs only brief qualification; the
second claim, on the other hand, warrants a quick rehearsal of recent
scholarship on utopian form.
Debates on realism tend to be period-based, addressed to the
defining features of nineteenth-century novels in England, France,
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
or the US, often those of George Eliot, Honoré de Balzac, or William
Dean Howells. These debates are not the purview of this essay,
though the historicity of such realist claims does inform my argu-
ment. What defines my outlook on the realist mode, then, is the kind
of conceptual response it has been to the material situation it would
represent. When Jameson notes that "in Balzac the weight of empiri-
cal being, of history and accumulated event, is apparently still light
enough for alternative histories to be imagined," he marks a phase
in realist practice in which the author's "Utopian libidinal investment"
is behind a bid to constitute reality by representing it; this phase,
Jameson argues, is exhausted when "in high realism, such alterna-
tive narrative registers begin to disappear" and in their place appear
"a kind of obligatory 'indicative' register."
We can revisit how this
"indicative" mood, the stubbornness of social facts as is, narratively
hardens into naturalism, but the generic consequence for this col-
lapse of narrative registers, as Jameson influentially argues, is that
realism floats free of the historical novel and comes to animate "the
Utopian or science-fiction novel" (Political 193).
In a study on American realism, Amy Kaplan further develops
Jameson's idea of realism. She refers to the switchover at which
realism cedes to naturalism, but disputes the more precipitate di-
agnosis that American literary realists deployed what Jameson calls
a "strategy of containment," which would "fold everything which is
not-being"—meaning change as such—"back into the status of nature"
(193). The interesting move Kaplan makes, and one that explains
why she refrains from using the term "naturalism" in assessing this
period, is the move to restore dynamism to the period's literature,
to show that while naturalist description might have been emergent
at the turn of the century, it was by no means dominant.
The fact
that style then became a matter of either public avowal or disavowal,
moreover, suggests that the disinterestedness of anyone proclaim-
ing to reflect social life was subject to heated contest. The arena
for producing "the real," Kaplan submits, had pitted the novelist's
struggle "to represent reality against contradictory representations"
(6). Style, in this account, is the realist calling card. "To call oneself
a realist," Kaplan writes, "means to make a claim not only for the
cognitive value of fiction, but for one's own cultural authority both
to possess and dispense access to the real" (13).
Theorized in this fashion, it is easy to see how Butler, committed
to SF stylization, will not consider style an impediment to her realist's
task of "capturing, wrestling, and controlling" the historical vocation
of the LA Civil Unrest.
The unembarrassed relation that SF has with
style—the notion that "facts seem to alter with an altered voice," as
Ursula Le Guin has written (2)—is what makes Butler's representa-
Menne
tion of the event an ethical one; her style tenders itself as a form of
cultural authority, as an alembic through which private perception
will offer itself as new terms for public debate. Butler's mirror (recall
Stendhal's "mirror moving along a highway" [297]) "is not only a
reflecting one," in Suvin's words, but "is also a transforming one"
("Poetics" 374). Following from this, my second historical claim, that
Butler's realism is therefore ineluctably utopian, is the more contro-
versial. Indeed, Butler repudiates it herself. "Personally, I find utopias
ridiculous," she once remarked (Moylan, Scraps 323). Yet against her
will, it would seem, or rather in keeping with the historical trajectory
of the form, Butler has teased utopian traits from the violence enacted
against the state, and against the ongoing racism of its institutions,
that would make the LA Civil Unrest not simply the brutality found
in the folds of nature, but the harbinger of historical possibility, only
several years after history famously "ended."
What accounts for
Butler's resistance to utopia, I suspect, are those historical images
of atrocity underwritten by utopian projects, perhaps The Reign of
Terror or Stalin's gulags. Any of these iterations of utopia imagine
that history vanishes and all the activities of social life are somehow
programmed into the biology of human beings. Killing the noncompli-
ant human beings is, in such backward theories, a principle of natural
selection, not a social project. When Butler qualifies her disdain for
utopias—"We're not going to get a perfect society until we get a few
perfect humans" (323)—she is not criticizing utopias, but rather this
tendency to decouple utopia from material history and then use its
ideal as a means to deflect the social impulse toward self-betterment.
In this perverse form, utopia has been an alibi for state repression,
and a worthy target for criticism; but utopia, of all forms, can never
be reified in these ways without becoming its opposite.
That Butler should criticize utopia as a nonhistorical project only
puts her in step with, rather than against the grain of, the historiciz-
ing approach to the genre taken by Utopian Studies.
Phillip Wegner
argues in this vein that "the great twentieth-century works" in the
utopian genre are all committed to "remaking the form so that it
will be adequate to a changing experience of modernity" (Imaginary
Communities xxiii). Utopia cannot be a static form, that is, and it has
been Tom Moylan's work, most indefatigably, to historicize it, showing
how utopia works its way out from under its misappropriations. The
utopian writings so widespread in the nineteenth century, Moylan
remarks, were counteracted in the development of a dystopian, and
sometimes fully anti-utopian, tradition in the twentieth century; the
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
canonical examples being Yevgeny Zamyatin's We, Aldous Huxley's
Brave New World, and George Orwell's 1984. At times a seeming
repudiation of their utopian predecessors, and as such a literary
matter, novels in this tradition must, however, be assessed in the
extraliterary context of modern state form, most crucially in its ten-
dency toward a totalizing control of the historical forces that might
undo it. But "against this dystopian tide," as Raffaella Baccolini and
Moylan have recently argued, "the oppositional political culture of the
late 1960s and 1970s occasioned a revival of distinctly eutopian writ-
ing, the first major revival since the end of the nineteenth century"
(2), only this time the impulse was not strictly for utopia to become
critical of society, but to become self-critical. However, the era of
critical utopias came to an end, Moylan notes, when in the 1980s
such leaders as Ronald Reagan, Margaret Thatcher, and Helmut Kohl
hitched this utopian spirit to the project now known as neoliberal-
ism (Scraps 184).
It is within this regime, one presuming to leave
behind ideological contestation in market synchronicity, that Butler
tries to ground her writing. Forswearing utopia, though for Butler it
may seem mere pragmatic acknowledgment of history's persistence,
is in her case the utopian act.
This sounds like a paradox, no doubt. But what she wishes to
do is root utopian vision in material conditions, to return the stress
to the empirical situation, hence permitting such vision a transforma-
tive value rather than just a conservative function. In short, Butler
restores dialectics to utopia. We can hear Butler's concern for the
need to calibrate social dreaming against one's current historical mo-
ment, the hard necessity of it, when her protagonist, Lauren, notes
that the efficacy of the solutions she proposes—and problem-solving
is for her a kind of pastime—owes to her immersion in the problems.
"I live in this world, too," she remarks, as though she were by proxy
offering Butler's caution against the negative side of utopian form
that can never admit any positive content (230). This describes the
flaw in conservative utopia, whose dangers Hegel first touched on in
Philosophy of Right, with broad reference to the Rousseauian volonté
générale, or general will, that leads to revolutionary Terror. In that
state of "pure indeterminacy," as Hegel describes it, as too in the
utopian state cleft from material realities, there is the "dissipation of
every restriction" that materiality imposes. Here, "it is only one side
of the will which is described, namely this unrestricted possibility of
abstraction from every determinate state of mind which I may find
in myself or which I may have set up in myself, my flight from every
content as from a restriction" (22). When Lauren Olamina develops
her credo, in a series of epigrams whose centerpiece is historical
change ("God / Is Change," she writes), she insists that adapting to
Menne
material realities is what immunizes community life against "destruc-
tive fanaticism" (1); this is to say that the will to construct social life,
rather than acquiesce to it as given, as some deep current of nature,
is the true utopian project. When the utopian project fails to adapt to
this determinate content, "when representative thinking regards this
side by itself as freedom"—"the unrestricted possibility of abstrac-
tion," that is—"and clings fast to it," as Hegel writes, "then we have
negative freedom," which, turned into "actual practice," "takes shape
in religion and politics alike as the fanaticism of destruction—the
destruction of the whole subsisting social order—as the elimination
of individuals who are objects of suspicion to any social order, and
the annihilation of any organization which tries to rise anew from
the ruins" (22).
In this regard we might place Butler's self-professed anti-
utopianism alongside Hannah Arendt's critique of the state-of-nature
theory that gave a negative utopian drive to the Jacobin purges.
Both Butler and Arendt key their critiques to political developments
in which such emptied out utopian forms abet violence. If for Butler
it is the neoliberal imperative to overlook violence, and do so by call-
ing it irrational, then for Arendt it is the scarcely comparable French
Revolution. What Butler and Arendt share is a critique of the way the
actors involved impute the change afoot to forces beyond the human
pale. Arendt understands the collapse into the Terror on the order of
a literary problem, deeming a description of politics naturalist (by any
other name) that would leave man's goodness outside the domain of
political life. Because "the goodness of man in a state of nature had
become axiomatic for Rousseau" (79), Arendt reasons, such goodness
becomes categorically "incapable of establishing 'lasting institutions'"
(86). Therefore, "when the men of the French Revolution said that
all power resides in the people," Arendt writes, "they understood by
power a 'natural' force whose source and origin lay outside the political
realm," and in this way they rendered agency a "pre-political, natural
force of the multitude and they were swept away by it" (181). Theirs
was a commitment, hence, to a set of literary naturalist descriptions
of power: Robespierre's tempête révolutionnaire, Desmoulins' torrent
révolutionnaire, and Georg Forster's "lava stream of the revolution,"
all variations on the "metaphors of stream and torrent and current"
"in which the revolution is seen not as the work of men but as an ir-
resistible process" (Arendt 49). Nature, from this perspective, is the
name for a process without plasticity.
Crucially for Butler, this literary presentation of a goodness and
power derived from some past in which people need not codify such
innate virtues, and in fact would only corrupt them in the effort to
institutionally preserve them, is dystopian. Moreover, making one-
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
self subject to nature, rather than making one's nature subject to
construction, is antithetical to SF. Butler thematizes this quiescent
outlook—one in which subjects have no input in their present, but
only admiration for their original, irretrievable state—in the form
of religious belief. "A few believe God is another word for nature,"
Lauren muses, "And nature turns out to mean just about anything
they happen not to understand or feel in control of" (13). But this
quiescence is not couched in religious terms as a broad repudia-
tion of religion as some instrument of power; rather, religion serves
only as a figure for ideology, for the orientation people have toward
their own agency within a political system. This becomes clear when
Lauren, who casts her own political disposition in religious terms,
differs with her father's politics—a dispute which, of course, must
be carried out in religious language because the two place action as
such in a cosmological setting. Her father accepts that "some won't
do anything at all. There are always people who won't do anything"
(59). And religion, as he sees it, does its proper work when it allows
those "denying reality," as Lauren puts it, to deny, in turn, the hand
they have in helping it along its course. Otherwise, they would panic
at their own liability. Lauren, in contrast, cannot bear her father's
position, nor the related one taken by her friend, Joanne: "Why do
you want to talk about this stuff," Joanne asks Lauren, "We can't do
anything about it" (48). What Lauren comes to develop as a religion,
then—an "idea? Philosophy?" she wonders (23)—is in fact a mode of
representing the space she inhabits within a total system. On deign-
ing to understand it, and the Promethean urge to claim agency this
bespeaks, she experiences first a moment of doubt: "Is any of this
In this moment, I submit, she invokes the "real," and
its volatility, because she now intends to produce it. She constitutes
herself as a realist, and a utopian therefore, because she prefers the
"Belief" that "Initiates and guides action," according to her credo,
rather than the belief that "does nothing" but assent to a closed
system, which is, as suggested, dystopian (41).
The key move for Butler is not to wish away one's material
situation but to inscribe one's place within it. In this regard Lauren's
reminder—"I live in this world, too"—is our invitation to not only
consider the materialist core to Lauren's outwardly spiritual beliefs,
which is nothing but dialectics, after all; it is our invitation, too, to
consider Los Angeles as the terrain for Butler's narration. Calling on
Los Angeles as a kind of system marked by spectacular violence—the
spectacle of which, in fact, threatens to unmoor it from systemic
causality—brings to mind what Jameson says of how "bound up"
Thomas More's Utopia is with his "real empirical world" (Archaeolo-
gies 38). Jameson notes that in the movement toward the text's
Menne
capacity to establish its own autonomy, it creates an "autoreferential
allegory about the structure of the representation itself, which still
depends on external references and empirical contents" (39). We
find something like this at work, mutatis mutandis, in Parable of the
Sower, when Butler plots her relation to the Los Angeles uprising by
way of placing the Olamina family in the suburb of Robledo, some
"20 miles from Los Angeles" (9). Giving this middle-class family a
suburban vantage on the urban crisis, especially in the moment it
erupts in violence, is Butler's means for allegorizing the very structure
of representation that leads to what appears in the media as the LA
Riots. This is not simply to say that the media view of the LA Civil
Unrest is a suburban view, but rather that a view favoring the sub-
urbs is behind the state policies that at once created the conditions
for the upheaval and yet cannot recognize any causality within it.
While we could make the narrow observation that, since Butler lived
in Pasadena at the time, Lauren's view of Los Angeles from Robledo
roughly equates with the author's own view of the LA Civil Unrest,
it is more to the point that Butler produces this structure—an urban
decay that must be represented by the suburban spectator as the
end of civilization—because she wishes to indict these conditions as
those general to neoliberal policies.
Hers is a utopian practice as we shall discern if we place it next
to Mike Davis's similar writings on Los Angeles as the exemplary out-
come of neoliberal strategies.
Davis writes of "the gated communi-
ties manufactured by Kaufman and Broad" whose developments he
regards as "a polemic against incipient urbanism" meant to assuage
"a new, burgeoning fear of the city" (City of Quartz 6). He gives an
anatomy of those fears, raised by "the consequences of market-driven
overdevelopment," the "decades of systematic under-investment in
housing and urban infrastructure," which he notes was "begun by the
Carter administration in 1978 but enshrined in the Reagan Revolu-
tion" (7). All this "combined with grotesque subsidies for speculators,
permissive zoning for commercial development, the absence of ef-
fective regional planning, and ludicrously low property taxes for the
wealthy" to undermine "the quality of life for the middle classes in
older suburbs as well as for the inner-city poor" (7). Davis's reports
on the city will curiously mime Butler's, at key turns; however, his
will take on a more standard scholarly aspect by deploying raw data
amid other forms of analysis. For all the raw data, though, what
should prompt us to marshal his work alongside Butler's here is his
urge to take Los Angeles as a metaphor for neoliberal conditions.
On the ruins of Llano del Rio, an erstwhile experimental community
in the desert outside Los Angeles, Davis asks two Salvadoran con-
struction workers what they think about Los Angeles, "a city without
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
borders" that "dream[s] of becoming infinite." The workers say that
Los Angeles already is "everywhere." The vision, indeed, comes all
too easily to Davis of this city "reproducing itself endlessly across the
desert with the assistance of pilfered water, cheap immigrant labor,
Asian capital, and desperate homebuyers willing to trade lifetimes on
the freeway in exchange for $500,000 'dream homes' in the middle
of Death Valley" (12).
In Parable of the Sower, Butler will first construct the middle-
class glimpse of the violent upheaval in Los Angeles, as a threat once
safely at bay but now dangerously near. "We hear so much gunfire,"
Lauren says from within their gated neighborhood of the proximity
of violence, "day and night, single shots and odd bursts of automatic
weapons fire." Being within these gates, Lauren considers herself
on "an island surrounded by sharks," but these are "land sharks,"
she remarks, "on their way in" and it's only "a matter of how long it
takes for them to get hungry enough" (44). As she and her family
feel the urban crisis now overtake them, she wonders if this augury
of class war, so undeniable for the middle class, is now intelligible to
the rich as well: "although perhaps with their big guns, private armies
of security, and up to date security equipment," Lauren thinks, they
may be able to withstand it (104). But if Butler first constructs this
view of Los Angeles as a system unto itself—if, like Davis, "it is the
accelerated decay of the public sector that best explains the rising
tensions" not only in Los Angeles but "elsewhere" ("Who Killed Los
Angeles" 10)—she does not endeavor to generalize it in the same
spirit as does Davis, whom David Harvey has accused of conferring,
at times, a "doom-laden sense of historical inevitability" ("Reflections"
63) on the neoliberal project that, in Davis's words, abandons big
cities to "the animal spirits of urban capitalism" (12), grants suburbs
"autonomy from the crisis of the core cities" (17), and "dismantle[s]
the citizenship entitlements of the urban and rural poor" (19). Butler's
account indeed acknowledges the "Magna Carta for privatization"
drafted on the authority of a neoliberal perception of urban decay
as the natural outcome of a rotten welfare state. In Lauren's world,
after all, "no one call[s] the fire department" anymore because no
one "would take on fire service fees," such are the gutted provisions
of the state (28). Yet in Butler's account, the violence occurs not as
the inevitable death knell for Los Angeles, and thereby for the social
order tout court, but as a flash that illuminates once occulted relations
within the totality of which Los Angeles is a scaled model.
In LA's moment of violence, in other words, Lauren sees not
the eclipse of all social order, but the eclipse of a social order. Rather
than see these as end times, she sees revealed the popular power
that could, if properly managed, help reconstitute society in sets
Menne
of relations whose symmetry would not require their false self-
representation as the only order that human nature can issue. This
is utopian sight in an anti-utopian time. Lauren must clarify for her
friend, Joanne, the opportunity in such so-called rioting by recalling
for her that the bubonic plague, because it was catastrophic, called
for responses. "Things changed for the survivors," she says, "but it
took a plague to make some of the people realize that things could
change" (49). Catastrophe lights up the reified world, Lauren rea-
sons, so that one might see the moveable parts in social life. This
operation is typical of utopian texts, Jameson argues, as they must
first negate the conditions that obstruct any view of their ameliora-
tion. What the negation does, as Lauren's case attests, is allow her
"imagination to overleap the moment of revolution itself," as Jameson
puts it, "and posit a radically different 'post-revolutionary' society"
(Archaeologies 16). This frees Lauren from the tug of her empirical
world, which in Mike Davis's account can implacably reproduce itself,
and lets her instead set radically new ways—a novum, as Suvin would
call it—against the efforts taken by politicians of the status quo to
redouble the structure that produced destruction in the first place.
We see people surrounding Lauren doing just that. One reaction in
Laurens' suburb is to buy guns and be armed for class war. "It's my
father's fault that we pay so much attention to guns and shooting,"
Lauren says, "He carries a nine millimeter automatic pistol whenever
he leaves the neighborhood" (33). And at the level of official strategy
President-elect Donner "has a plan for putting people back to work,"
Lauren informs us. "He hopes to get laws changed, suspend 'overly
restrictive' minimum wage, environmental, and worker protection
laws for those employers willing to take on homeless employees and
provide them with training and adequate room and board" (24). Vio-
lence is met with violence, more of the same is prescribed, because
the manifestation of power—the "moment of revolution" that Lauren
overleapt but that swept away many others—is being mistaken for
constituted power, what Arendt has called "lasting institutions."
What has supported the mistaken perception of a power that is
inchoate with one that is formally constituted—as the fait accompli, in
this case, of humanity's anarchy-prone power, each against each, in its
natural state—is the capacity of representation to place its beholders
in their role as "merely spectators," as Lukács says of the naturalist
mode (116). When Arendt remarks of revolutionary power that "most
manifest in this spectacle was that none of its actors could control
the course of events," her language suggests an emergent tendency
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
in bourgeois statecraft to convert would-be participants into specta-
tors, the same tendency found by Lukács in the age's literature. The
conversion is effected, as we see many times over, by describing a
people's power in terms of the sublimity of nature. Lukács finds an
emblematic site for such a representation in Émile Zola's descrip-
tion of the theater "only from the point of view of the audience," the
passive situation of which extends to his characters at large and his
readership, too (113). Butler's Parable novels constitute themselves
as forms of representation opposed to this relation between an aloof
spectator and an unmovable object-world that reaches an apotheosis
in the image, as Guy Debord argued in his manifesto, The Society
of the Spectacle. The Parable novels pointedly do so because the LA
Civil Unrest was touched off by the image of Rodney King's beating,
an image-event that Sanyika Shakur found not at all "unusual given
the current relations between the New Afrikan community and the
police" but which became an oddly autonomous signifier, Shakur sug-
gests, through "the repeated sight of it actually happening" (380–81).
The televised image of King's beating, though, joins a stream of
such images of urban riots dating back to the 1960s; indeed, it was
this televised exhibit in which urban unrest took on a kind of natural
rhythm which Hayden early on contested, lest its social character be
lost in the "constant, even-tenored stream," as Lukács puts it, from
which violence bursts as unintelligibly as "'sudden' catastrophes"
(122). Davis notes, too, how such an image stream seems to be a
neoliberal hallmark, wherein "the fuzzy video images of the Marines
or 82nd Airborne in the streets of Panama City, Miami, Los Angeles,
Grenada, or Mogadishu all look alike and the prone figures on the
ground are always Black" ("Who Killed Los Angeles" 7). This, we
should pause to note, is the obverse side of the image of Los An-
geles made ubiquitous, as the Salvadoran construction workers tell
Davis, by television. In the image that reached these men in San
Salvador, "everyone was young and rich and drove new cars and
saw themselves on television," but on leaving home and arriving at
"Alvarado and Seventh Streets in the MacArthur Park," these men
found, Davis reports, that no one like them "was on television; they
were all invisible" (City of Quartz 12).
In Parable of the Sower, when Butler wishes to undo the pecu-
liar spell of the spectacle—which, as Debord says, is "the opposite of
dialogue" (17)—she has the last television go dark. Huddled around
"the last big Window Wall television" in a neighborhood house, ev-
eryone watches "whole blocks of boarded up buildings burning in
Los Angeles" before "the Window" goes dark (16). Eliminating the
image, in fact, functions as the very precondition for narrative. Once
this seeming "vast, open window" onto the world shutters, once
Menne
the "Window Wall" returns to some earlier state as a "Wall," Lauren
begins writing her political verses on change. Though Butler writes
SF, a genre committed to roundabout figuration rather than straight-
forward reports, we need not read her gesture ingeniously to take
it for what it is: a call for an interactive medium, a dialogue, and a
repudiation of supine assent to television images. Butler hints that
the neighborhood is not rich enough to have computer interaction,
but she here imagines the corporeal engrossment of virtual reality
("They couldn't afford to subscribe to any of the new multisensory
stuff . . . no reality vests, no touch-rings, and no headsets" [17])
rather than the open forum of the Internet. What Butler proposes as
a counterforce against the spectacle is writing and reading, and the
recursivity between the two. When Joanne beseeches Lauren, "What
can we do?," they have seen the televised riots and are gripped by
desperation. Lauren takes "several books from the bottom drawer"
and shows them to Joan: "This is what I've been doing," Lauren says.
Joanne calls her response insufficient, "Books aren't going to save
us" (51). And we should agree with her, if by books she thinks of a
hermetic denial of the world beyond them, most urgently the unrest
beyond their walls. But Lauren means books as a return to language,
it would seem, first in their critique of the image as a bearer of public
debate—image would seem to arrest debate, instead—and second in
favor of feeding public debate with new terms.
Here we need to recognize not just what historically motivates
the Parable novels—in short, the image-event of Rodney King's beat-
ing and the ensuing violence—but how it is that Butler has become
self-reflexive about the role writing has in adding historical purpose
to an event that, left alone, could license whatever response officials
find efficacious. Butler's novels, on one hand, reinsert the image of
the beating into a context of historical causation, to show, as Lukács
would have it, that "'sudden' catastrophes are actually long in prepa-
ration" (122); on the other hand, they help control the afterlife of
this image. In this respect the second novel, Parable of the Talents,
allegorizes two responses to the LA Civil Unrest in the stories of Lauren
and Marcus Olamina, in terms of the cultural authority on which their
responses depend. In the first novel, when the Olamina neighbor-
hood, Robledo, was burnt down, Lauren's younger brother, Marcus,
was presumed dead. Lauren responds to LA's collapse by enlisting the
image of its rent body politic—called "a carcass covered with too many
maggots" by Lauren's father (8), this depiction of LA as a maimed
body invoking, perhaps, Rodney King as icon—as the patron image
in the formation of an alternative community, later called Acorn. She
rallies a community, which features "the best qualities of the identity
politics of the 1980s," Moylan remarks, "even as it reconfigures that
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
entire tendency within the emerging alliance politics of the 1990s"
(237), and she does so with the aid of her Earthseed writings. When
Marcus resurfaces years after his alleged death, writing has helped
his return: Lauren assimilates his "impossible" return by writing about
it ("Writing about it helps. Somehow, writing always helps" [101]),
but Marcus too claims to have survived so long, in some sense, by
being an able writer. Early on, "there was a hell of a business in fake
paper," Marcus tells Lauren, and because "people couldn't read or
write or at least not in English," Marcus "wrote some of it" (132).
In Acorn he becomes a figure of literary prowess in competition, one
might say, with his sister's literary demiurge. Whereas Lauren's design
for community life is that its members rotate in teaching each other
and sharing their skills, Marcus disagrees with this ethos: "I'm not
out to teach a class," he says, "I want to preach a sermon" (162).
In other words, Marcus wants to revive the authoritarian style of the
old order ("For I am the Lord," he quotes, "I change not" [163]),
and he does so by joining Christian America, while Lauren wants to
radicalize the way community works by drawing authority from those
formerly cast to the margins. The polarized response to violence in
LA, then, is either to batten it down, by using a mixture of police
force and religious fundamentalism to prop up an internally conflicted
authoritarian state, or to call forth from it the repressed power of a
multitude and constitute it as a basis for self-government.
But the allegory in Parable of the Talents is not limited to soci-
ety's two poles of response to the outbreak of violence. The strong
or expanded form of allegory concerns the place writing fills in the
more general project of acting on the events of social life, such that
we can now reckon Butler and SF writing into this contestatory arena
in which jostle the different kinds of writing that would gain narra-
tive control of the present. Consider that Butler not only thematizes
the act of writing, whether Lauren's or Marcus's, but also derives
the very form of the novels from collaging written texts, theirs and
others. Parable of the Sower, for instance, is made of Lauren's diary
entries, interspersed with her Earthseed verses. The effect is to run
the quotidian up against the spiritual (though I am wary of constru-
ing the Earthseed verse as spiritual, in a narrow sense, when in fact
this is but the available language in which Lauren gives a theory
of historical change).
This novel, then, takes the form of Lauren
theorizing her experience. But this split in textual materials, first only
subjective in its offer of Lauren's two angles of vision, is placed on
expanded foundations in the second novel when Lauren's daughter,
Larkin, functions as the curator of a more heterogeneous group of
texts: Lauren's two texts from the earlier novel, the Earthseed books
and her diary, now formally titled The Journals of Lauren Oya Ol-
Menne
amina, Marcus's memoir, Warrior, and the account given by Lauren's
husband Bankole, Memories of Other Worlds. Larkin moves between
these texts in an effort to coordinate the historical record, for finally,
this is what the Parable novels allegorize: the genres for represent-
ing history. Butler crosses a variety of such genres for the sake of
disclosing what Hayden White would call the "ideological component"
in each one (Metahistory 21). If Larkin seems to hold a privileged
position vis-à-vis these accounts, it's not because she escapes ideol-
ogy, by any means, but because she occupies the standpoint of the
next generation from which these accounts appear properly historical.
She can critique Lauren's ideal, claiming that her mother was more
demagogic than theoretically honest: "She needed large events to
manipulate" (2). And here we should take Larkin's remove from her
mother not as one safeguarding Larkin's own interpretation against
ideology—using the word manipulate, after all, is a literary choice—
but rather as one homologous to our remove, as readers, from the
accounts that we, like Larkin, must assemble into history.
If we take seriously that Butler allegorizes the historical record
as a formal device for writing LA's spectacular violence into an SF
framework, clarifying both its source and vocation, we should in turn
take seriously what she supposes fiction can do: it works, it seems,
to leave the historical record agape. We can assess Butler's effort to
keep the LA Civil Unrest an unfinished event, then—a prehistory to
Lauren's utopian Earthseed, as it were—using a metric that Kaplan
calls the "cognitive value of fiction" (13), this time with an eye on what
the science additive does to realist fiction. White has described what
it takes for a text, specifically an historical account, to become "cog-
nitively responsible" (23). For White, a text's willingness to avow the
ideology that will skew its rendering of events is a form of openness
that makes it "epistemologically self-conscious." Such historical imagi-
nation is underpinned by "value systems that claim the authority of
'reason', 'science', or 'realism'" (23), and in the fact that these forms
of authority depend on self-criticism—realism, when not passed off
as disinterested reflection, is authority of this kind—lies their fitness
for public debate. SF keeps alive the realism so vital in constituting
public meanings because science, as its preferred figure of thought,
furnishes it not with unchecked authority—the inviolability of the as
is—but rather with an outlook on historical time as mutable, plastic,
and open to society's review. Turning to one feature from the Parable
novels, a feature that also signals them as SF, we can see how this
works. Lauren is a sharer, or empath, which is a pathology causing
her not to share in another's pain or pleasure, but to be under the
delusion that she cannot help but share in that pain or pleasure. In
other words, Lauren believes herself biologically geared to participate
Octavia Butler and the State of Realism
in a just society. She cannot live at the cost of another's pain, as
her biology decrees. But there is something witty about the fact that
Butler, in challenging a bipolar society that is the "inevitable" product
of human nature, on the neoliberal account, would make what Lauren
considers a biologically-encoded conscience a matter of psychologi-
cal delusion. These behaviors, as Butler's use of science suggests,
are socially acquired, but then naturally explained.
Science holds
open the competing possibilities of what society must be. Hence, that
Butler would use the LA Civil Unrest as the impetus for Lauren to
plan a series of utopian communities is not so curious, after all, for
what critical and popular response to her novels implies is that many
readers have found in their oblique approach to these events the
buried narrative, and thereby the sense of future purpose, in what,
as pure spectacle, had riveted attention without offering up a politics.
1. See "Analysis of the 1992 Los Angeles Civil Unrest," http://www.usc.
edu/libraries/archives/cityinstress/analysis/main.html.
2. "SF, happily or unhappily," as Samuel Delany says, "is the initials
of both" science fiction and speculative fiction (x). When I use the
initials, I have no investment in differentiating the two.
3. My account of SF realism will differ from certain prior accounts due,
chiefly, to the theorists of realism on whom I rely, namely Fredric
Jameson and Amy Kaplan, in the pages below. To cite an argument
on SF realism with different theoretical presuppositions, J. Timothy
Bagwell has argued for SF as a form of realism in his essay, "Science
Fiction and the Semiotics of Realism." While I designate realism as
a form of writing with self-conscious designs on constructing what
counts as our real world, Bagwell uses realism in the sense of veri-
similar codes that allow narration to hang together credibly as a real
world. "Science fiction," Bagwell says, "is the imposition of the code
or style of realism on the fantastic" (41). The "inclusion of excessive"
detail helps, in this project, as such details suggest "the lifelikeness
of the fictional world" (42). My argument will take objection with this
leg of Bagwell's argument as its sense of unmotivated detail maps
onto the Lukácsian naturalism that I will place at odds with SF. Yet
in the closing paragraphs of Bagwell's argument, he does approach
the argument I will make for SF. "The function of science fiction as
a plot structure," he claims, "is not to reveal to us how things are
but to change our way of thinking about how things are" (47). And,
it is "worth remembering, though, that the reader's world is itself
to a large extent fictional, at least to the extent that it is a function
of various unreflected codes that condition its interpretation" (47).
Referring to the empirical world as itself "fictional" seems to me
Menne
infelicitous language, when "constructed" would seem to make the
point as well without casting into doubt this world's realness. But
Bagwell's argument, if only briefly, chimes with my own here because
he makes the point that most efforts to construct a real world fail to
disclose their "codes" as ostentatiously as does SF.

5. In "Narrate or Describe?," Lukács analyzes Zola's writing in terms of
his penchant for "description" (110). Lukács subordinates the value
of description to narration because the former recuses the witness
from the action whereas the latter embeds the witness in the action.
"In Zola the race is described from the standpoint of an observer; in
Balzac it is narrated from the standpoint of a participant" (111 italics
original).
6. For an insightful study of the effects media had on New Left activism,
with special attention given the status of image, see Todd Gitlin's

J. Boorstin's The Image.
7. I adopt the term "image-event" from Joshua Clover's study of pop
music during the last days of the Cold War, 1989. In demonstrating the
equivocal use of various images, notably those images the Western
press used to "explain" the events of Tiananmen Square, he invokes
the "image-event" as "empty analysis, and empty representation and
opinion" (115).
8. Michael Davitt Bell provides this quote from Norris. For more nuanced
discussion of Frank Norris's "revolt against style," see his The Problem
of American Realism, chapter four. For my purposes, Bell's important
point on Norris is how the author's dissembling of literary quality, or
style, resembled the ruling-class claim to objectively report "real-
ity." Norris's "idea of reality," Bell argues, "is almost always tinged,
or more than tinged, with sexism and racism; white, Anglo-Saxon
males always seem to have a corner on the 'real'" (120). For the
ethics of "public-sphere debate," see Jürgen Habermas's seminal
The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere, in particular the
subsection of section II, "The Public Sphere in the World of Letters
in Relation to the Public Sphere in the Political Realm."
9. The argument quoted from appears in Jameson's The Political Uncon-
scious, but he offers a related argument, with SF in the foreground, in
an essay appearing a year later in Science-Fiction Studies, "Progress
versus Utopia, or, Can We Imagine the Future?" There he elaborates
the claim that "the moment in which the historical novel as a genre
ceases to be functional, is also the moment of the emergence of SF"
(Archaeologies 284).

19. Tom Moylan has criticized the second Parable novel for lapsing into

course" (244). Wegner has offered a more sanguine take on the

20. In Parable of the Talents, Lauren describes this willingness to excuse
our social failures as natural inevitabilities in explicit terms:
We go on having stupid wars that we justify and get passion-

people, maim others, impoverish still more, spread disease
and hunger, and set the stage for the next war. And when we
look at all of that in history, we just shrug our shoulders and
say, well, that's the way things are. That's the way things have
